It seems that those download are no more working...

... Meanwhile, I kept the "1.2.1 stock version" updated (I'm not playin RSS, so I didn't look on those config) to KSP 1.0.4, in my games (with a bit of adaptation in some stats here and there).

Mostly notable changes to the original Baha upload:

- textures switched to .dds

- updated configs to 1.0.4 thermal values

- BNTR, unlike stock NERVA, still work on liquid fuel + oxidizer: that means you can use rocket fuel, BUT it goes VERY hot in 3-4 mins of full thrust. ADD properly radiators if you are planning interplanetary burns!!!

- ARES V plate is a 5 meter diameter thrust-plate: out of scale in a pure stock game (better suited if used with some other mod bigger rocket fuel tanks)

- RS-68B engine is balanced to the stock S3 KS-25x4 "Mammoth" Liquid Fuel Engine: it has 1/4 of the Mammoth thrust (mimic a single nozzle engine based from the same), and same ISP stats (it means, added to the ARES V plate, that you have a 6x cluster of comparable engines)

I didn't upload to any official site, pending Bahamuto approval, but you can download it here:

https://www.dropbox.com/s/ovbrf88hlehw7qi/BahaConstellation_1.2.1_edit1.0_KSP1.0.4.zip?dl=0

--- Updated URL to Dropbox hosting ---

On 1/29/2016 at 6:19 AM, Natskyge said:

Dies this work with realisme overhaul in 1.0.5?

It looks like at least some of the parts were configured for RO recently:

https://github.com/KSP-RO/RealismOverhaul/commits/master/GameData/RealismOverhaul/RO_SuggestedMods/BahamutoD

 

The updates were made recently enough that they aren't in the official (ie. CKAN) release of RO yet, but if you 'Download ZIP" and use the Github version of RO, that will be your best bet.

https://github.com/KSP-RO/RealismOverhaul
By the way their are different versions of copernicus.

On 22.04.2014. at 9:50 PM, BahamutoD said:

Woowoo! I got leg suspension to work! Not spring hinges though unfortunately, but I don't think those are currently possible (I don't know of any parts that use them, stock or otherwise).

Here's a quick test. Obviously the settings of the legs in the video are super OP, but you get the idea.

 

 

Edit: Oh also, its using PhysicsSignificance = 1 in the video. Without it, there would be alot of forward/backward flexing.
